MIXTURE

A mixture can be defined as a substance/material made up of two or more different elements or compounds which are mixed together but are not combined chemically but physically combined and can be separated by physically e.g separation techniques can be used to separate a mixture but not for compounds, thus a mixture can be made up of different compounds. They can be in the form of alloys, solutions, suspensions and colloids. 

Mixtures are separated by specialized physical means, Iron or sulphur would react chemically with steam, dil. HCl and dil. NaOH but both have no reaction with benzene. 

Separating funnel is used to separate immiscible liquids, a polar and bipolar solvent (e.g. oil and water). The lower dense layer is tapped off leaving the upper less dense. 

Sieving is a separation technique used in separating solid particles of different sizes.

Evaporation to dryness is used to recover a solid solute from a solution. Solvent is sacrificed. 

Distillation is used to recover a solvent from a solution. It is also used for separation of miscible liquid. 

Crystallization is used to separate salts, which decompose easily on heating, from their solutions. The salt crystals obtained in this way are pure, and usually contain water of crystallization.

Crystallization is used in industries where purity of products is important as in the manufacture of drugs and sugar production. This is not so with precipitation which tends to bring other solutes out of solution. 

Precipitation tends to bring other solutes out of solution.

Decantation is used to separate insoluble solid from a liquid, after allowing the mixture to settle by standing it for a while. 

NB: Sodium chloride is a compound chemically produced. Sea water is a mixture of sand, water and salts. Iron filings is an element existing alone. Granulated sugar is a simple compound.

Example

A mixture of sand, ammonium chloride and sodium chloride is best separated by to

A. sublimation followed by addition of water and filtration B. sublimation followed by addition of water and evaporation C. addition of water followed by filtration and sublimation D. addition of water followed by crystallization and sublimation (2014/2015 no 1) D

Answer

Addition of water will dissolve sodium chloride(salt) followed by crystallization and sublimation which removes ammonium chloride leaving the sand behind.

 

 

 

A chemical change is characterized by their inability to be reversed due to formation of new substance that cannot be separated by physical means. dissolving powdered sulfur in carbon disulfide is not a chemical reaction. 

The addition of Water to quicklime is an example of a chemical change.

The more the impurity present in a pure substance, the lower the melting point. Impurity lower melting point and the same time increase the boiling point. This is applied in cold countries where people put antifreeze to their car radiator and sprinkle salt in iced road, this result in melting of the ice.

Boiling point and vapour pressure are inversely related. Therefore, the higher the vapour pressure of a liquid, the lower it’s boiling point.

If the liquid is in an open container and exposed to normal atmospheric pressure, the liquid boils when its saturated vapour pressure becomes equal to 1 atmosphere (or 101325 Pa or 101.325 kPa or 760 mmHg). This happens with water when the temperature reaches 100°C.

Hygroscopic substances are those substances which when exposed to air, it absorbs the atmospheric moisture but does tum into solution. This is unlike deliquescent, that is, they absorb moisture and turn into solution.

Examples of hygroscopic substances are; concentrated sulphuric acid, potassium hydroxide, sodium hydroxide, zinc chloride and calcium chloride etc. 

A colloid is a heterogeneous system in which one substance is dispersed (called dispersed phase) as very fine particles in another substance called dispersion medium. Soap lather is a colloidal system in which gas (air) is dispersed in soap solution which is the dispersion medium.

In suspensions, the solid particles do not dissolve in the liquid or gas - this makes them different from solutions. An aerosol is a suspension of fine solid particles or liquid droplets, in air or another gas.

Aerosol spray is a type of dispensing system which creates an aerosol mist of liquid particles. It is example of a suspension of solid particles in a gas

Haze is an example of suspension.

Two types of solder are commonly used. One is a soft solder, which is an alloy of tin and lead. The other is a hard solder, which is an alloy of copper and zinc.

Brass is a metal alloy that is always made with a combination of copper and zinc.

Bronze is an alloy consisting primarily of copper, commonly with about 12–12.5% tin and often with the addition of other metals (such as aluminium, manganese, nickel or zinc).
